body: The package is only used when explicitly requested through `go run build.go proto`. The results of that command are checked into the repository, so there should be no need for Debian to consider this dependency during package builds.

@acolomb,

> The package is only used when explicitly requested through `go run build.go proto`. The results of that command are check into the repository, so there should be no need for Debian to consider this dependency during package builds.
>

The package appears to be required within a Debian context:

`
dh_auto_build -- -ldflags "-X github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/build.Version=v1.18.6-ds1 \
                                   -X github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/build.User=debian \
                                   -X github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/build.Host=debian \
                                   -X github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/build.Stamp=1648854604" \
                           -tags 'noupgrade purego'
        cd _build && go install -trimpath -v -p 4 -ldflags "-X github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/build.Version=v1.18.6-ds1                                    -X github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/build.User=debian                                    -X github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/build.Host=debian                                    -X github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/build.Stamp=1648854604" -tags "noupgrade purego" github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/stcompdirs github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/stdisco github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/stdiscosrv github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/stevents github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/stfileinfo github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/stfinddevice github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/syncthing/generate github.com/syncthing/syncthing/cmd/uraggregate github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/api github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/api/auto github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/discover github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/discover/mocks github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/events github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/events/mocks github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/fs github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/ignore github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/locations github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/logger github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/logger/mocks github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/model github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/model/mocks github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/nat github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/rand github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/rc github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/relay/client github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/relay/protocol github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/scanner github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/sha256 github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/signature github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/stats github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/stun github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/svcutil github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/sync github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/syncthing github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/testutils github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/tlsutil github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/upgrade github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/upnp github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/ur github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/ur/contract github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/util github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/versioner github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/watchaggregator github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/weakhash github.com/syncthing/syncthing/proto/ext

        /usr/lib/go-1.18/src/github.com/gogo/protobuf/gogoproto (from $GOROOT)
        /<<PKGBUILDDIR>>/_build/src/github.com/gogo/protobuf/gogoproto (from $GOPATH)

        /usr/lib/go-1.18/src/github.com/gogo/protobuf/proto (from $GOROOT)
        /<<PKGBUILDDIR>>/_build/src/github.com/gogo/protobuf/proto (from $GOPATH)
src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/proto/ext/ext.pb.go:9:2: cannot find package "github.com/gogo/protobuf/protoc-gen-gogo/descriptor" in any of:
        /usr/lib/go-1.18/src/github.com/gogo/protobuf/protoc-gen-gogo/descriptor (from $GOROOT)
        /<<PKGBUILDDIR>>/_build/src/github.com/gogo/protobuf/protoc-gen-gogo/descriptor (from $GOPATH)
src/github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/config/observed.pb.go:9:2: cannot find package "github.com/gogo/protobuf/types" in any of:
        /usr/lib/go-1.18/src/github.com/gogo/protobuf/types (from $GOROOT)
        /<<PKGBUILDDIR>>/_build/src/github.com/gogo/protobuf/types (from $GOPATH)
`
We rely quite extensively on the features gogo proto provides for custom code generation via extensions.

Yeah... I did this migration recently in a different project, because it was required to use newer gRPC and other libraries, and let me tell you it's a pain in the ass. And Syncthing does more custom stuff than that other thing did. So, I think this should be somewhere on our radar for the far future, as we're currently a little bit stuck in a dead end, but it's not a small or quick thing.

@sten0 I'm trying to replicate this, but having trouble trying to build it under Ubuntu 20.04 LTS.  Shouldn't a `dpkg-buildpackage --no-sign -d` work from a checkout of your Salsa repo?

@syncthing/maintainers what is the import of `_ "github.com/gogo/protobuf/gogoproto"` supposed to mean in the generated .pb.go files?
Underscore imports are generally done for side effects. I don't know the specifics, you'd have to check the package.

That package has init functions that need to run:

https://github.com/gogo/protobuf/blob/226206f39bd7276e88ec684ea0028c18ec2c91ae/gogoproto/gogo.pb.go#L708-L787

Hi!

Thank you for discussion, reply follows inline:

greatroar ***@***.***> writes:

> That package has init functions that need to run:
>
> https://github.com/gogo/protobuf/blob/226206f39bd7276e88ec684ea0028c18ec2c91ae/gogoproto/gogo.pb.go#L708-L787

Audrius Butkevicius ***@***.***> writes:

> We rely quite extensively on the features gogo proto provides for custom code generation via extensions.
>

Yes, this is what it looks like to me too :-)

Jakob Borg ***@***.***> writes:

> Yeah... I did this migration recently in a different project, because it was required to use newer gRPC and other libraries, and let me tell you it's a pain in the ass. And Syncthing does more custom stuff than that other thing did. So, I think this should be somewhere on our radar for the far future, as we're currently a little bit stuck in a dead end, but it's not a small or quick thing.
>

Yeah, this kind of work is no fun.  I believe that the reason my
colleague asked me to contact the Syncthing project may be due to
concern that the currently-unmaintained gogo protobuf will break when Go
1.19 is released, similarly to how quic-go broke with 1.18; however, I'm
not sure how likely that is.  To be fair, there are also at least the
following two alternatives:

1. Perhaps form a team with other projects who use gogo protobuf, and
adopt its maintenance?

2. Perhaps form a team to work on a compatibility layer, similarly to
Marten Seeman's qtls-go1-18?

Speaking from a Debian context, this second option would become
nonviable if gogo protobuf itself fails to build with a future version
of Go.

Regards,
Nicholas

> concern that the currently-unmaintained gogo protobuf will break when Go 1.19 is released, similarly to how quic-go broke with 1.18;

What's that concern based on? quic-go is not a good example, it's replicating internal go library code that needs to be adapted on every release, thus the qtls-<goversion> package. That has nothing to do with gogo-protobuf.

@acolomb 

> @sten0 I'm trying to replicate this, but having trouble trying to build it under Ubuntu 20.04 LTS.  Shouldn't a `dpkg-buildpackage --no-sign -d` work
 > from a checkout of your Salsa repo?

 Attempting to build Syncthing 1.18.6~ds1-1 (or newer) on Ubuntu 20.04
 will fail early during dependency resolution, at a minimum, because
 golang-github-marten-seemann-qtls-go1-18-dev exists exclusively in
 Debian sid/unstable as of two days ago.  If your interest is in
 providing a Debian-Policy-compliant package via PPA for Ubuntu 20.04,
 then I'd recommend the following general-case backporting strategy:

 1. Backport (or ask to have it backported) 1.18.6~ds1-1 to bullseye,
 making adjustments as necessary.  Some dependencies may also need to be
 backported.  At the moment I'm focused on sid/unstable, but when I have
 free time I'd be happy to help with this effort.  At this point you'll
 have a package that works on Debian 11 (bullseye).

 2. Branch 1.18.6~ds1-1~bpo11+1 to jammy-backports, make adjustments, and
 don't forget to use the Ubuntu `dch` options to generate the correct
 "~ubuntu" suffix.  Some dependencies may also need to be backported, and
 should be provided in the PPA.  If I remember correctly the state of
 Debian sid/unstable and testing is currently about 2.5 months newer than
 Ubuntu 22.04.  At this point you'll have a package that works on Ubuntu
 22.04, that will provide smooth upgrades when users upgrade to Ubuntu
 22.10 (fast stream) or Ubuntu 24.04 (LTS stream).

 3. "Sloppy" is a Debian convention that indicates the packages is not
 taken from stable_release +1, but from what will become stable_release
 +2.  Upgrades skipping stable distribution releases are not supported,
 and this convention helps users and admins identify packages that may
 cause a "failed to upgrade" state.  I believe this is also why Ubuntu
 upgrade instructions recommend removing packages installed via PPAs
 before upgrading between major versions of the distribution.  Create a
 focal-backports-sloppy branch by branching from either:

   a) jammy-backports (ideally the release tag), or
   b) 1.18.6~ds1-1~bpo11+1, and apply the same adjustments as the
   jammy-backports branch.

 4. The next step is to apply another round of adjustments that may be
 required to backport a package that works on Ubuntu 22.04 to Ubuntu
 20.04.

 Yeah, this method is a lot of work, but that's the cost of providing
 newer software with on LTS releases with verifiability, reproducibility,
 reusability by downstreams, etc--and without needing to provide a
 "upgrades unsupported" disclaimer.  This is the "how" of why upgrades
 between stable Debian releases go smoothly, and likely the reason why
 Ubuntu is based on Debian.

 If you're actually asking how I tested that protobuf was required, here
 is how to replicate my experiment.

```diff
 diff --git a/debian/control b/debian/control
 index b2f8931d3..b9cf9d708 100644
 --- a/debian/control
 +++ b/debian/control
 @@ -26,7 +26,6 @@ Build-Depends: debhelper-compat (= 13),
                 golang-github-d4l3k-messagediff-dev,
                 golang-github-golang-groupcache-dev,
                 golang-github-oschwald-geoip2-golang-dev,
 -               golang-github-gogo-protobuf-dev (>=1.2.1+git20190611.dadb6258),
                 golang-github-lib-pq-dev,
                 golang-github-minio-sha256-simd-dev,
                 golang-github-audriusbutkevicius-pfilter-dev,
 @@ -84,7 +83,6 @@ Depends: ${misc:Depends},
           golang-github-d4l3k-messagediff-dev,
           golang-github-golang-groupcache-dev,
           golang-github-oschwald-geoip2-golang-dev,
 -         golang-github-gogo-protobuf-dev (>=1.2.1+git20190611.dadb6258),
           golang-github-lib-pq-dev,
           golang-github-minio-sha256-simd-dev,
           golang-github-audriusbutkevicius-pfilter-dev,
```
 I saw no reason to make the Salsa project unbuildable, merely as an
 experiment, so didn't push this commit ;-)  'Hope this helps!

 Cheers,
 Nicholas

Hi,

I asked this on IRC. The reason is that gogo/protobuf is unmaintained for 2 years, see https://github.com/gogo/protobuf/issues/691

This concern is not related to Debian packaging, but a general dependency concern.

I don't intend to build a PPA version, no. Was just asking because I wanted to investigate why it's needed at all for a git checkout where the .pb.go files are already present. But that has been clarified.
